carousing-lower.result: You are jailed for 1d4 days at the end of the downtime period on charges of disorderly conduct and disturbing the peace.
You regain consciousness in a strange place with no memory of how you got there, and you have been robbed of 3d6 x 5 GP.
You made an enemy. This person, business, or organization is now hostile to you. The DM determines the offended party.
You are caught up in a whirlwind romance. Roll a d20. On a 1-5, it ends badly; the other person now has a hostile attitude toward you. On a 6-10 the romance fizzles. On 11-20 the romance is ongoing.
You have earned a gambling debt of 1d6 x 10 GP to an NPC who is not happy about nonpayment.
You earned a reputation for rowdiness. Locals are wary of you; Charisma checks with them have disadvantage for 1d6 days.
You accidentally insulted a guild master, noble's servant, or similar important figure.
No complication. You had a great time!

carousing-upper.result: You are jailed for 1d4 days on trumped-up charges during the downtime period.
You accidentally insulted a noble. The noble demands an apology or a duel.
You made an enemy among the upper class. The DM determines the offended party.
A whirlwind romance with a noble complicates matters. Roll a d20. On a 1-5, their family opposes you. On 6-10, the romance cools. On 11-20, it flourishes.
You were challenged to a high-stakes game by a noble. You owe 1d6 x 50 GP or a favor.
You've been invited to an exclusive event, but a rival plans to embarrass you there.
A political scandal erupts connected to your socializing. You're implicated in a rumor.
No complication. You made an excellent impression.

crime.result: A bounty equal to your earnings is put on your head.
An associate betrays you. Details are up to the DM.
You left evidence that could lead to your arrest. The authorities are investigating.
You stole from someone with powerful connections. That person sends agents after you.
A rival criminal gang becomes aware of your activities and marks you as a target.
You picked up a cursed item during the heist. It's among your loot.
A witness saw your face. They might talk unless dealt with.
No complication. It was the perfect crime.

pit-fighting.result: An opponent swears revenge against you.
A crime boss approaches you with a request to throw your next fight.
You were injured during a bout. You take 2d6 damage that can't be healed by magic.
A noble or wealthy merchant takes notice of you and wants you to fight on their behalf â€” for better or worse.
You unknowingly defeated a local champion; their fans are hostile toward you.
Accusations of cheating are leveled against you, whether true or not.
You attracted the attention of a talent scout for gladiatorial games in a distant city.
No complication. Your victories were clean.

religious-service.result: You have offended a priest through ignorance of ceremony or doctrine.
A rival within the temple seeks to undermine your standing.
You discover the temple is involved in questionable activities.
A zealous member of the faith demands you undertake a quest to prove your devotion.
You accidentally revealed a temple secret to an outsider.
The temple asks you to make a significant donation (1d6 x 10 GP) to prove your faith.
A congregation member falsely accuses you of heresy.
No complication. Your service was exemplary.

general.result: You unknowingly offend a guild master, attracting unwanted attention.
A rival adventurer spreads rumors about you, damaging your reputation.
You attract the attention of a local thieves' guild, who wants a cut of your action.
A mysterious stranger approaches you with a dubious proposition.
You witness a crime. The criminals know you saw them.
An old rival or enemy learns of your location and begins making plans.
A merchant accuses you of passing counterfeit coins, whether true or not.
